You need to modify the `prepareInstructions` function to use the exported `AIResponseFormat` constant instead of requiring it as a parameter: ```typescript export const prepareInstructions = ({ jobTitle, jobDescription, }: { jobTitle: string; jobDescription: string; }) => `You are an expert in ATS (Applicant Tracking System) and resume analysis. Please analyze and rate this resume and suggest how to improve it. The rating can be low if the resume is bad. Be thorough and detailed. Don't be afraid to point out any mistakes or areas for improvement. If there is a lot to improve, don't hesitate to give low scores. This is to help the user to improve their resume. If available, use the job description for the job user is applying to to give more detailed feedback. If provided, take the job description into consideration. The job title is: ${jobTitle} The job description is: ${jobDescription} Provide the feedback using the following format: ${AIResponseFormat} Return the analysis as a JSON object, without any other text and without the backticks. Do not include any other text or comments.`; ``` This removes the `AIResponseFormat` parameter from the function signature and uses the constant directly. Looking at the `prepareInstructions` function in `constants/index.ts`, it uses the `AIResponseFormat` parameter that's passed to it, but you want to use the `AIResponseFormat` constant that's already defined in that same file. You need to modify the `prepareInstructions` function to use the exported `AIResponseFormat` constant instead of requiring it as a parameter: ````typescript path=constants/index.ts mode=EDIT export const prepareInstructions = ({ jobTitle, jobDescription, }: { jobTitle: string; jobDescription: string; }) => `You are an expert in ATS (Applicant Tracking System) and resume analysis. Please analyze and rate this resume and suggest how to improve it. The rating can be low if the resume is bad. Be thorough and detailed. Don't be afraid to point out any mistakes or areas for improvement. If there is a lot to improve, don't hesitate to give low scores. This is to help the user to improve their resume. If available, use the job description for the job user is applying to to give more detailed feedback. If provided, take the job description into consideration. trying to access a special `.well-known` URL that your React Router app doesn't have a route for. This is a common issue during development. The URL `/.well-known/appspecific/com.chrome.devtools.json` is used by Chrome DevTools for debugging purposes, but your app doesn't have a route to handle it. **Quick fix:** Add a catch-all route to handle these requests. Update your `app/routes.ts`: ```typescript import { type RouteConfig, index, route } from "@react-router/dev/routes"; export default [ index("routes/home.tsx"), route("/auth", "routes/auth.tsx"), route("/upload", "routes/upload.tsx"), route("/.well-known/*", "routes/well-known.tsx"), ] satisfies RouteConfig; ``` Then create the handler file: ```typescript export default function WellKnown() { return new Response("Not Found", { status: 404 }); } ``` **Alternative approach:** If you don't want to add routes, you can ignore these requests by adding error handling in your `app/root.tsx` ErrorBoundary, but the route approach is cleaner for development. This should stop the error from appearing in your build process.
